title: Ladakh Takes The Lead
text:
JAMYANG TSERING NAMGYAL, parliamentarian from Ladakh, tells MONA MEHTA that his dream is to achieve a clean, green and pollution-free Ladakh



The 34-year-old MP from Ladakh, Jamyang Tsering Namgyal, made famous recently by his advocacy speech in Parliament — with reference to Ladakh becoming a Union Territory — was in New Delhi at the launch of the Green Himalayas project initiated by two NGOs, Go Green, Go Organic, led by His Holiness Drikung Chetsang Rinpoche, and Goldenmile Learning, founded by Rajesh Patel and Srini Srinivasan.



When asked what his concerns were regarding climate change and Ladakh, he said that everyone in Ladakh and other regions of the Himalayas depend on glacier-fed water for sustenance. “Their whole existence is at stake because the glaciers are melting rapidly. And why is this happening, are the people in Ladakh alone responsible for polluting the atmosphere? No, the problem is rooted in the plains. The heat and pollution generated in the plains is heating the atmosphere in the upper regions and with the result the glaciers there are melting rapidly.



“The core issue in Ladakh is the environment, for we have a fragile ecological system, climate and topography.



Whatever and however we develop Ladakh, it will not be at the cost of the environment. That is our primary concern and it is very heartening to see that each and every resident of Ladakh is fully aware of this,” says Namgyal.He goes on to spell out the action he would take in order to achieve a cleaner environment: “Green practices are not limited to a certain section of people; they are important not only for human beings but for all sentient beings. We all need to contribute to it, because without water and oxygen no one can survive. Everyone wants to lead a happy and healthy life, and you cannot expect to usher these into your life without a green, clean environment. Hence, every citizen has to get involved.”Namgyal informs that Ladakh banned single-use plastic 20 years ago at the initiative of the Women’s Alliance, whose members were not educated but had a high level of awareness. “When I was chairman of the Ladakh Autonomous Hill Development Council, we banned the use of firecrackers. They cause noise, soil and air pollution, and frighten birds and animals. Recently, when we got the Union Territory status, we celebrated with great pomp and show but without bursting a single cracker,” he says.What does going green mean to the young and enthused MP? He replies, “To go green does not mean merely planting more trees. It means to do a lot more to combat climate change, protect the environment and preserve this fragile ecosystem. To go organic means increasing the sustainable livelihood of the people organically, increasing everyone’s earning power, and also ensuring that all sentient beings are taken care of. Now that masters such as Drikung Chetsang Rinpoche, the founder of Go Green Go Organic, have shown us the way, it has become easy for us, the younger generation. We don’t have to look for solutions, we only have to take the project forward and save the world and us.”Isn’t Ladakh being a popular tourist destination also contributing to degrading its natural assets? While admitting that tourism is indeed a thriving sector, and yes, irresponsible tourists could create problems, Namgyal voices concern about the quality rather than volume of footfalls in the region. “We are working to promote responsible tourism,” he says.And how can we become responsible tourists? “Avoid anti-environment activities, for example. When you come on a road trip, please drive on the road, don’t disturb the wildlife there, don’t drive on the lake or over pastural land where goats, sheep, marmot and many other animals and birds thrive,” he says.
